message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of deep venous thrombosis and presents with left ankle swelling, distended veins, and pitting edema. The erythematous scaling patches on the medial side of the left ankle suggest stasis dermatitis. Duplex ultrasonography can confirm the diagnosis by showing the direction of blood flow. Blood flow from the popliteal vein to the small saphenous vein would suggest reflux, a common finding in patients with chronic venous insufficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of distended, tortuous veins and pitting edema suggests a venous insufficiency. Erythematous scaling patches suggest stasis dermatitis. The previous deep venous thrombosis episode and the patient’s BMI puts her at increased risk for chronic venous insufficiency. The most likely direction of blood flow to confirm the diagnosis would be Popliteal vein to small saphenous vein, indicating reflux in the superficial venous system.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of deep venous thrombosis, and the symptoms suggest chronic venous insufficiency. The direction of blood flow indicated in option (B) is consistent with retrograde flow in the small saphenous vein, which is a common finding in chronic venous insufficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of deep venous thrombosis and present with left ankle swelling and distended, tortuous veins in the legs bilaterally. The erythematous scaling patches on the medial side of the left ankle may suggest stasis dermatitis, and duplex ultrasonography is performed to confirm the diagnosis. Popliteal vein to small saphenous vein direction of blood flow will most likely confirm the diagnosis as it is a common location for venous insufficiency and may show reflux of blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's previous history of deep venous thrombosis and current symptoms of left ankle swelling suggest a possible recurrence of DVT. Duplex ultrasonography is the preferred diagnostic test and the direction of blood flow from the popliteal vein to the small saphenous vein can confirm the diagnosis of DVT. Options A, C, and D are not typically associated with DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history and symptoms suggest a possible recurrence of deep venous thrombosis. Duplex ultrasonography is often used to diagnose DVT, and the direction of blood flow can confirm the diagnosis. In this case, blood flow from the popliteal vein to the small saphenous vein would suggest a thrombus in the popliteal vein or proximal to it.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and medical history suggest a possible diagnosis of post-thrombotic syndrome. Duplex ultrasonography can help confirm the diagnosis by visualizing the direction of blood flow. In post-thrombotic syndrome, blood flows from the popliteal vein to the small saphenous vein due to valve damage or incompetence. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of deep venous thrombosis and current symptoms suggest a possible recurrence. Duplex ultrasonography is used to diagnose deep venous thrombosis, and the direction of blood flow from the popliteal vein to the small saphenous vein would confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and physical examination suggests venous insufficiency and edema. Duplex ultrasonography can confirm the diagnosis by showing retrograde flow from the popliteal vein to the small saphenous vein (B). The other options do not involve the small saphenous vein, which is often implicated in venous insufficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of deep venous thrombosis, and the symptoms suggest post-thrombotic syndrome. The duplex ultrasonography will confirm the diagnosis by showing blood flow from the popliteal vein to the small saphenous vein.
